intro: Ochthodium aegyptiacum, commonly known as the Egyptian thornapple, is a flowering plant belonging to the nightshade family, Solanaceae. It is characterized by its spiny stems and lobed leaves, which are adapted to arid environments. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that give way to orange or red berries, which are toxic to humans but serve as a food source for certain wildlife. Native to North Africa and the Middle East, it thrives in dry, rocky soils. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and medicinal research.
